author: Slow Hand
content:
It's a big topic, but gain staging is about finding the optimal amount of gain at every stage of the recording and mixing process.

Good gain staging allows you to get the best fidelity out of a recording by preventing things from creating unwanted distortion or amplifying unwanted noise. **OR** if you are *seeking* some distortion and compression it's about turning up the gain enough to give you the amount that you're seeking from your tools.

Gain staging is something to be considered at all steps of the production process. For example:

*1. How loud is an amplifier turned up in the room? Is the microphone being blow out by it?

2. How high is the gain on a microphone preamp and is it at risk of clipping if the performer plays loudly?

3. Is the gain so low that when I turn a signal up later on the noise floor will rise with it?

4. If I'm recording to tape, am I recording quiet enough that it won't saturate the signal, or do I want for the signal to slam the tape and be saturated?

5. How loud is an individual channel in a DAW? Is it making the channel clip?

6. How loud is a signal that's being sent into a piece of hardware or a plugin? Am I distorting the circuitry at all?

7. Is my signal coming in so hot that it makes a compressor react way too hard?

8. How loud is the entire track I'm mixing? Is the limiter crushing the dynamics in an unwanted way? Or am I hitting it just with just enough level to get a certain flavor of pumping and clipping?

9. Is my final mix going to hit digital zero and create unwanted clipping?*

So gain staging is not a single thing, but a series of choices that are made every step of the way around how you manage the "voltage" of your signals. Together these choices all add up to a mix that "breathes" well and is free of excessive or unwanted distortion.

author: Isaac Diskin
content: Any basic digital multimeter that you can get at Harbor Freight, Home Depot etc will do the trick! If you generate tones (sin waves) in your DAW or with an external device you can measure AC voltages at the various points you are interested in, and calibrate if need be. It’s important to understand what various decibel levels translate to in voltage, as that is what you would be measuring. For example, +4dBu = 1.228 Volts, and -10dBV = 0.316 Volts. But like the other answer said, unless you need to calibrate your outputs for a specific reason, you will be fine connecting various pieces of pro-audio gear as long as you pay attention to the gain staging and adjust gain as necessary so there’s no clipping. And if you need to interface with a consumer level device you’d probably be better off getting a bump-box or something of the like.

author: Zack Hames
content:
Here goes…
Million ways to skin this cat. I’ll give you food for thought.

1. At least double track. My personal goal, is to get the sound to be as awesome and huge and perfect with 1 pair of guitar tracks doubled, with 1 mic on an amp. That’s the ideal scenario for me. That said There are people that sum 4 mics down to 1 signal on a mixer and it sounds amazing.  

2. The more performances  you add of the same part, the more blurry it will sound.if you need different textures, consider recording a DI so it can be blended in with your amp in any manner of your choice, either reamping, distorting with a plugin, whatever. (Check phase)

3. I like when the left and right are *subtly* different, no drastically different. You hear “the left and right being different is what makes something wide”
This is true. But I loathe when it’s so different it feels lopsided.

How do we address this? 

-double track using the same guitar so the tuning and intonation is most similar 

-change the amp head but keep the same cabinet/speaker so the overall EQ is similar but my the gain structure is different

If you use 2 different guitars, consider the scale lengths. This will change subtle intonation things, for better or worse.

Another way to see this, at least the harmonics that clipping adds, is considering a simple sin wave vs a square wave. Read into the harmonics created (it’s just wave theory). But it’s especially clear in synthesis in that case.

Of course musical applications are much more complex, but that’s why clipping (squaring off the top of a rounded waveform) adds harmonics

That’s what people mean when they say it spreads the energy across the spectrum. In the case of a sin wave, you have a single fundamental. At the far other end, you have a square wave which has harmonics all up the spectrum of frequency

author: Rob Domos
content:
If it’s the hissing kind of noise that you get more of when you switch from condensers to dynamics and ribbons, then it’s not the kind of noise that is coming from the room. 

In rooms the main things you would be concerned about would be reflection (which you fix with treatment) and mechanical noise from things like computer fans, clocks, etc. and condenser mics would pick those kinds of sounds up more, not less. 

Any unison pre in the Apollo should be plenty low noise to not bother you on your condenser mics. I agree with others that not using any unison pre will make the noise floor lower, but I disagree with them in that I think using the unison pres is a pretty good idea often. 

That said, if you’re struggling with noise, definitely try not compressing on the way in because compressors are only going to raise the noise floor. 

On dynamic mics and ribbon mics, you can decrease your noise floor pretty considerably by picking up a cloudlifter and throwing that in the chain. 

If you do all of the above and still have a high noise floor then either the Apollo is broken (which is pretty unlikely), or your microphone is picking up mechanical noise from your air conditioning, computer fan, refrigerator, etc. if those are the issue, then tackle the issue there. Turn off the A/C, turn off the fridge, turn off the LED lights, etc and see what you hear.

author: cian riordan
content:
Template:
I’ve attached a slimmed down version of my mix template with all of the drum bussing. This has evolved over many years and has taken many forms, but it’s really just a good starting point for me and speeds up my workflow quite a bit. I’ve got three main busses that feed into a master drum buss. ‘DRUM SUB’ is my uncompressed (or lightly compressed) buss. ‘DRUM PAR’ is my heavily compressed buss, and ‘DRUM DIST’ is my parallel distortion buss. I don’t necessarily always use these, but having them ready to go makes it easier to quickly audition different ideas. Sometimes I’ll duplicate one or two of them to get another flavor involved. Again, everything to taste. 

Also in the template are some very basic aux’s I find myself using often. There are two parallel SansAmp busses. I have two because often times if I use one on the kick drum, it rarely works for the snare drum, so I have a second one ready to go. There’s also a ‘SNARE SLAP’ and ‘SNARE GATE VERB’ that rarely get used but if I need to inject a little mojo, they’re a good starting point.

The ‘D SUB TRIM’ is just a master fader controlling everything going into the bussing, so if I get a little overzealous with level, I can manage the gain staging quickly without having volume automation grouped. These three (sometimes more) busses then feed into the final ‘DRUM MSTR’ , where I’ll do final overall EQ tweaks and level adjustments.

author: cian riordan
content:
This is a very broad question with many different answers, but I think the easiest way to sum up the concept of ‘gain staging’ is simply figuring out what level every ‘device’ is expecting and/or which level is ideal to get the results you want. These ‘devices’ can be a plugin, a piece of hardware, an A/D/A converter, an auxiliary bus, a mix bus, etc.

In analog world… there might be fathomable difference when a compressor or amplifier receives -10dBVU vs +10 dBVU. Accounting for these differences would be considered gain staging — and you’d be looking for what gets the ideal sound out of your box.

In digital world… some plugins may react similarly and others may not care if you’re sending -6dBFS or -0.01dBFS. It’s usually case by case as there are myriad plugins. You also need to consider what level the plugin is sending signal out — as this will affect how the next plugin processes the audio, or how much headroom it has to work with. Let’s say I’m sending signal out of a compressor plugin into an EQ plugin — and lets say I’m using the compressor to beef up mean volume of the signal and then I want to EQ some more low end into the signal after the fact. Well, I’m going to be adding gain in the compressor and then the level going into the EQ will be hotter than originally intended. Id want to trim down the output of the compressor (or the input of the EQ) so you have headroom to be able to boost those frequencies without clipping the output of the EQ. In a 32-bit floating mixer like Pro Tools, these issues become less audible as the mixer has higher headroom than its indicating, but you never actually know — and it’s best to just stick to the parameters that you have control over. If you were to do this same function with an analog compressor and EQ, there would be very noticeable distortion if you didn’t stage the gain properly.

author: cian riordan
content:
Sometimes gain staging is just managing the signals going to an auxiliary bus or a master fader. If you’ve got everything summing into - say - an aux bus in pro tools, and that aux bus is clipping, then that will be audible distortion going into the next gain stage. It may sound good, it probably doesn’t — so its something to account for earlier down the chain. If you’re going into a master fader in pro tools, and your signal is over 0dBFS, you can simply turn down the master fader, and it is actually turning down all the signals going to it, not just the output. This is useful because you can then throttle the input to your first plugin in the chain — say a limiter or maximizer. It’d be a shame to have a fancy clipper on your master bus, only to be clipping the signal in the chain before even getting to it.

It’s a bit of a scattershot answer to a scattershot question, but the reality is that everything affects everything in audio. And having your head wrapped around signals levels going in and out of things will help you make faster decisions and help you troubleshoot quickly when things aren’t sounding quite right.

author: masteredbyjack
content:
To illustrate a good example of the difference and why (guessing) Jon would want to clip rather than do this (which would control the transients as you describe)

If you use a long look ahead, call it a limiter with a long look ahead. That will let the processor know about the transient well before it hits the GR circuit, thus avoiding distortion/harmonics (of course there still could be some artifacts). But even though there will be samples at the threshold, it won’t be a straight line waveform as if you clipped it. It is pushing the waveform down. The waveform itself is actually changed still, so it is not exact but it’s different than clipping.

A clipper just squares it off. Hence harmonics.

This is why you can limit/compress an instrument like piano, which has a tendency to hear distortion easily, when clipping it would be a disaster (unless you are going for that)
